content: The "Fueling America Act of 2009" includes provisions for increased production of natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicles, tax incentives for refueling property and vehicle purchases, as well as research and development projects and a clean school bus program. The "Fueling America Act of 2009" includes definitions for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas, with the Administrator and Secretary defined. It also covers research, development, and demonstration projects for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicles. The Secretary, in coordination with the Administrator, conducts a program for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicle research, development, and demonstration. The program aims to improve and develop cleaner, more efficient engines for various vehicle types, integrate these engines into vehicles for different applications, and assist manufacturers in meeting certification requirements and emission standards. The curr_chunk discusses California certification requirements, emission standards, operation of vehicles under all conditions, development of codes and standards, improvement of fueling station infrastructure, certification of infrastructure to safety standards, and enhancement of onboard fuel storage systems. The curr_chunk focuses on the certification of natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas fuel storage systems, development of new materials, certification of aftermarket conversion systems, and use of these fuels in hybrid vehicles. The program under this section focuses on streamlined certification for aftermarket conversion systems and coordination with the natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicle industry. It will be administered in accordance with the Energy Policy Act of 1992. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the Energy Policy Act of 1992 within 2 years of its enactment. $30,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014 to carry out this section. SEC. 103. STUDY OF INCREASING NATURAL GAS AND LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS VEHICLES IN FEDERAL FLEET. The Administrator of General Services, in consultation with the Administrator, will conduct a study on increasing natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicles in the Federal fleet, assess barriers, potential for maximizing use, and submit a report to Congress. SEC. 104. CLEAN SCHOOL BUS PROGRAM. Section 6015 of the Safe, Accountable, Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act is amended to increase the percentage of clean school buses with engines. The Safe, Accountable, Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act is amended to increase the percentage of clean school buses with engines manufactured in specific model years or fueled by certain gases, eligible for grants. The Safe, Accountable, Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act is amended to increase the percentage of clean school buses eligible for grants, with specific model years or fueled by certain gases. Section 741 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 is repealed. Tax incentives under Title II include a credit for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas refueling property. The amendment increases the credit percentage for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas refueling property under section 30C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment includes a special rule for qualified natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicle refueling property, increasing the credit percentage and maximum amount eligible for the credit. The amendment increases the credit percentage for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas refueling property under section 30C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes a special rule for qualified natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicle refueling property, increasing the credit percentage and maximum amount eligible for the credit. Substituting higher amounts for certain values is also specified. The amendment extends the credit for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas refueling property under section 30C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes a special rule for qualified liquefied petroleum gas vehicle refueling property, increasing the credit percentage and maximum amount eligible for the credit. The amendment applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2008, in taxable years ending after that date. SEC. 202. CREDIT FOR PURCHASE OF VEHICLES FUELED BY NATURAL GAS OR LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS. The amendment to section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increases the incremental cost limits for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicles by multiplying the dollar amounts by 2. Eligible vehicles include new qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles or aftermarket conversion systems. The amendment to section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increases the incremental cost limits for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicles by multiplying the dollar amounts by 2. Eligible vehicles include new qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles or aftermarket conversion systems capable of operating on compressed natural gas, liquefied natural gas, gasoline, or diesel fuel. The amendment to section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increases the incremental cost limits for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicles. An aftermarket conversion system converts a vehicle into an eligible natural gas or liquefied petroleum gas motor vehicle. The amendment to section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 extends the credit for natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas vehicles until December 31, 2014. The amendments apply to vehicles placed in service after December 31, 2008.
